reasoning: The critique targets one specific example (digital being governance) from Section 2.3.2, arguing that robust institutional design could mitigate the risk of moral catastrophe regarding digital beings. However, this example is just one of many illustrations supporting the broader argument that eutopia is fragile because value is multiplicative across many independent factors. The paper explicitly lists numerous other potential moral catastrophes (population ethics, wellbeing theory, resource allocation, discount rates, etc.) and notes the list is 'very far from exhaustive.' Even if the digital beings concern were fully addressed by good governance, the core argument—that achieving a mostly-great future requires getting things right across many dimensions simultaneously—remains essentially intact. This gives low centrality. The strength is also very low because the critique essentially says 'maybe society will design good institutions,' which is exactly the kind of optimistic possibility the paper acknowledges but argues against in its broader framework. The paper's point is precisely that getting digital governance right is just one of many challenges, and the probability of getting ALL of them right by default is low. The critique doesn't engage with the multiplicative model or the systematic analysis in Section 3. Correctness is moderate—it's true that good institutions could reduce specific risks, but the claim that this 'weakens' the paper's argument significantly overstates the case. Clarity is decent though somewhat generic. Single issue: focuses on one point.
title: Digital governance institutions could enlarge the eutopia target
